column21: Will bank adopt practices that seem ethical yet does not adopt othet practices that have a greater impact.

column20: If I were choosing a new bank now, I would pay more attention to sustainability. But I am lazy and want to avoid the hassle of changing, so the biggest practical factor is the ease of change. I don't even know what is required, I've never changed a bank, I'm just imagining that I'd need to report the change to many places, and I'm afraid I'd forget and then some payment may not go through, or people try to send me money and it doesn't work, and there will be trouble. So if a bank wants me to switch to them, they should provide information about practical details, where do I need to report the change, can there be some hassle and how to avoid it.
Educational/awareness initiatives in their business instead of just something "for show" + any exploitation of the poorer economies by passing the problem to them.
column21: it is fairly new and we don't hear enough of that. Investors generally worry does sustainability goals lead to a tradeoff in investment returns.
